title: Enel's Devil Fruit Originally Belonged to Thor of Elbaph
theory: The Goro Goro no Mi, revealed in Episode 173, may have originally belonged to Thor, a giant from Elbaph associated with thunder and lightning in Norse mythology. This theory suggests that Enel killed Thor to obtain the Devil Fruit, which would explain why Thor is missing from Elbaph and why a lightning-based fruit exists. The Great Tree Adam in Elbaph can reach the sky islands, providing a possible connection between Enel and the Giants.
author: Multiple One Piece community members
evidenceFor: Thor from Norse mythology is associated with lightning
The Great Tree Adam can reach sky islands
Thor is notably missing from Elbaph
Enel's god complex fits with killing a deity-like figure
evidenceAgainst: No direct confirmation in the manga or anime
Devil Fruits can appear anywhere when a user dies
No evidence Enel has ever been to Elbaph

title: Enel Will Return in the Final Saga
theory: Enel, whose overwhelming power was first demonstrated in Episode 173, will return during One Piece's Final Saga. The theory is supported by parallels between Enel and Imu (both destroy islands from the sky, have god complexes, use subordinates), and the potential that Enel learned important information about Sun God Nika on the moon. His Devil Fruit powers and knowledge could become relevant to the final conflicts.
author: One Piece community
evidenceFor: Oda has been bringing back fan-favorite characters in the Final Saga
Enel's moon mission cover story shows he discovered ancient technology
Parallels between Enel and Imu suggest thematic connection
Sky People worship Sun God Nika, which Enel may have learned about
Enel is still alive and ruling the moon
evidenceAgainst: Many fans are tired of this recurring theory
Enel's arc was conclusively finished in Skypiea
His location on the moon makes return logistically difficult

title: The Goro Goro no Mi's Introduction Foreshadowed Luffy's True Power
theory: Episode 173's revelation of the Goro Goro no Mi as an 'invincible' Logia fruit served as deliberate foreshadowing for the revelation of Luffy's Gomu Gomu no Mi being the Nika fruit. The fact that rubber counters lightning, presented as one of the most powerful Devil Fruits, hints at Luffy's fruit being more special than it appears. The matchup was too perfect to be coincidence.
author: One Piece theorists
evidenceFor: Oda plans far ahead with foreshadowing
The rubber-lightning matchup is too perfect
Skypiea heavily foreshadowed Sun God Nika
Luffy being the only one who could defeat Enel suggests destiny
evidenceAgainst: Could be simple logical weakness, not foreshadowing
Many other elemental matchups exist without deeper meaning

title: Nami Will Eventually Obtain the Goro Goro no Mi
theory: Some fans theorize that Nami, who fights using weather-based abilities and first used an Impact Dial in Episode 173, will eventually obtain Enel's Goro Goro no Mi. This would fit her weather theme perfectly and make her one of the most powerful Straw Hats. The theory suggests Enel will die in the Final Saga and his fruit will somehow reach Nami.
author: One Piece community
evidenceFor: Nami's weather abilities would synergize perfectly with lightning
She has already used electrical attacks with her Clima-Tact
Would give the Straw Hats a powerful Logia user
Oda has hinted at Nami's potential for greater power
evidenceAgainst: Nami's character arc is about navigation and intelligence, not raw power
No indication Enel will die or lose his fruit
The Straw Hats don't typically steal Devil Fruits from defeated enemies
Nami has expressed no interest in Devil Fruits

title: Enel's Invincibility Was Meant to Show the Importance of Haki
theory: Episode 173's demonstration of Enel's Logia intangibility and seeming invincibility was deliberate foreshadowing for the later introduction of Haki. Kamakiri's complete inability to harm Enel despite being a skilled warrior emphasizes that conventional strength isn't enough against Logia users, setting up the necessity for Haki in future arcs.
author: One Piece analysts
evidenceFor: Skypiea introduces Mantra, which is later revealed to be Observation Haki
The arc emphasizes that physical attacks can't harm Logia users
Oda was clearly setting up power system for future arcs
Enel's defeat by Luffy was only possible due to specific Devil Fruit matchup
evidenceAgainst: Haki wasn't fully developed as a concept until much later
Could just be demonstrating Logia powers, not specifically foreshadowing Haki
